Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: காலைக்குச் செய்தநன்று என்கொல் எவன்கொல்யான்மாலைக்குச் செய்த பகை.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: What good have I done to morning (and) what evil to evening?.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: A woman is shown in two states, bisecting the image. On the left, it is morning ('Kaalai'), and the time of day is personified as a kind, gentle friend who comforts her and gives her hope.
Layered_Composition.Midground: On the right, it is evening ('Maalai'), and this time of day is personified as a cruel, tormenting enemy who brings her immense sorrow and pain.
Layered_Composition.Background: The woman looks from one personified figure to the other with a bewildered expression, as if asking what good deed she did to earn the friendship of the Morning, and what terrible crime she committed to earn the enmity of the Evening.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: A lover's lament, questioning the vastly different nature of morning and evening. The morning is a friend, bringing a brief respite of hope, while the evening is a cruel enemy that amplifies her sorrow.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The personification of Morning as a kind friend and Evening as a cruel foe is the central visual.
Art_Direction.Mood_and_Emotion: Bewildered, questioning, a stark contrast between hope and despair.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The left (morning) side is filled with bright, gentle, hopeful colors—soft yellows and light blues. The right (evening) side is filled with dark, oppressive, painful colors—deep reds and blacks.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A balanced, split-screen composition that clearly shows the woman's relationship with the two personified times of day.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, allegorical realism, with creative and expressive designs for the personified Morning and Evening.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: Contrasting lighting schemes—soft and high-key versus dark and low-key.

Cultural_Anchors: காலை (Morning) as a time of hope
மாலை (Evening) as a time of sorrow
